text:
Hi, I mentioned these “issues” a while back. Doing some benchmarking and testing I found specific cases were the things i mentioned happened. They are not really affecting me, but gonna put them out there.

1. Not reading complete updates
```buffer_size = 4

msg = b"abc\r\n"```
If this is the last message in the stream then it won’t be read.

2. Delay because of having to read whole buffer

If Betfair produces messages faster than you can process (decoding/market_cache)
then you buffer will fill up and you will have to read the whole buffer before processing new messages.

``````

elements.text: Hi, I mentioned these “issues” a while back. Doing some benchmarking and testing I found specific cases were the things i mentioned happened. They are not really affecting me, but gonna put them out there.

If this is the last message in the stream then it won’t be read.

2. Delay because of having to read whole buffer

If Betfair produces messages faster than you can process (decoding/market_cache)
then you buffer will fill up and you will have to read the whole buffer before processing new messages.

text:
<@U92CASP1B>
1. my understanding is that bufsize is the maximum size, so using the <https://github.com/liampauling/betfair/blob/master/betfairlightweight/streaming/betfairstream.py#L218|bflw code> in your example two parts will be read from the socket and joined together 'abc' + '\r\n' 
2. not sure I would comfortable in processing streaming data on the fly, i.e before the entire message has been sent but I could see it being useful if you have very large subscriptions but even then does conflate happen that often? I have never had an issue

attachments.title: liampauling/betfair
attachments.text: Lightweight python wrapper for Betfair API-NG (with streaming) - liampauling/betfair

elements.text: my understanding is that bufsize is the maximum size, so using the
in your example two parts will be read from the socket and joined together 'abc' + '\r\n'

not sure I would comfortable in processing streaming data on the fly, i.e before the entire message has been sent but I could see it being useful if you have very large subscriptions but even then does conflate happen that often? I have never had an issue

text:
About #1

the recv parameters from my understanding is the amount the gets  transferred from kernel space, that way we can have many messages in  kernel space

here is an example

```from socket import socketpair


if __name__ == "__main__":
    s1, s2 = socketpair()

    s2.sendall(b"abc\r\n")

    print(s1.recv(4))
    print(s1.recv(4))
   
    # b'abc\r'
    # b'\n'

   ```

elements.text:
About #1

the recv parameters from my understanding is the amount the gets  transferred from kernel space, that way we can have many messages in  kernel space

here is an example

from socket import socketpair


if __name__ == "__main__":
    s1, s2 = socketpair()

    s2.sendall(b"abc\r\n")

    print(s1.recv(4))
    print(s1.recv(4))
   
    # b'abc\r'
    # b'\n'

text: They will be joined but it will keep trying to recv since we do not meet “\r\n” condition I think.

elements.text: They will be joined but it will keep trying to recv since we do not meet “\r\n” condition I think.

text:
As you say I do not think this will cause any real trouble,

Reading from socket from my observation is insanely fast, the thing that takes time is decode to json / market cache and queue

These can make the socket wait for reads which in turn can delay messages.

in extreme cases.

elements.text:

Reading from socket from my observation is insanely fast, the thing that takes time is decode to json / market cache and queue

These can make the socket wait for reads which in turn can delay messages.

in extreme cases.

text: I don’t see the problem, and must have processed close to billions of updates without any issues

elements.text: I don’t see the problem, and must have processed close to billions of updates without any issues

text: But yes agree about the decoding, good use case for some async I think!

elements.text: But yes agree about the decoding, good use case for some async I think!

text:
the problem can happen when market_cache updates takes time.

because you process and queues on the same thread as you are reading the socket.

the default recv is 1024 bytes, I kernel space you have 65k bytes normally.

If we start queing up messages in kernel space we probably have to read them all + more until processing again, instead of just queing them and then process.

text: As said just want to make it aware, maybe not a real problem can occur and can be hard to see why :slightly_smiling_face:

text: If you se a little delay before market cache process you can see the behaviour of almost reading forever from socket before processing
